definitions.sensetop: A differs from BA and B differ (from each other)differ between A and B

examples.text: French differs from English in this respect.
French and English differ in this respect.
examples.contextForm: A and B differ (from each other)

examples.text: Ideas on childcare may differ considerably between the parents.
His ideas differ little from those of his father.
Opinions differ widely on this issue.
Social organization differs significantly between the different groups.
The models differ in size and shape.
The rates of violent crime differed greatly among the four cities.
I have to differ with you on that.
Medical opinion differs as to how to treat the disease.
It didn't seem right that I should differ with him.
The two parties differ on all the major issues.
The two sides still differ over details of the plan.

definitions.definition: if two people agree to differ/disagree, they accept that they have different opinions about something, but they decide not to discuss it any longer

examples.text: We must just agree to differ on this.
In the end we agreed to disagree.
I think you're wrong. Let's just agree to differ.

definitions.definition: used to say politely that you do not agree with something that has just been said

examples.text: ‘At least she is good at her job.’ ‘Oh, I beg to differ.’

wordOrigin: late Middle English (also in the sense ‘put off, defer’): from Old French differer ‘differ, defer’, from Latin differre, from dis- ‘from, away’ + ferre ‘bring, carry’. Compare with defer ‘put off’.
